description: This course is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to: (1) provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, (2) provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making; and (3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.
name: CONSUMER BEHAVIOR

values.comments: Contemporary approaches to business emphasize the importance of adopting a consumer focus. Marketing, in particular, begins and ends with the consumer – from determining his or her needs to ensuring post-purchase satisfaction. The primary goal of this course is to enhance understanding of consumer behavior. By the end of the course students will be knowledgeable about consumer psychology and ways of better meeting people’s needs. During this process, students will come to better understand themselves as a target of marketing influence. Students will also appreciate how an understanding of consumer psychology can be used to develop powerful marketing techniques and tactics. The course also aims to provide an important competitive advantage: an ability to see how to have an impact on consumers, and hence a talent for making more insightful business decisions. This course is an examination of the factors (both internal and external) that influence people's behavior in a buying situation. Course objectives are: (1) to provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, integrating theories from psychology, sociology, and economics; (2) to provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions; and (3) to introduce behavioral research approaches. Marketing 101 is a prerequisite.   Overall, students enjoyed this course and the subject material. Most students agreed that this course had a “heavy slant on psychology” but that Professor Mellers “knows her stuff on that end” and made sure the material was clear to everyone. Students further remarked that the course actually combined “marketing and psychology in a way that is thought-provoking and applicable to the real world.” Students also enjoyed the guest lecturers for the course.   Students overall felt that Professor Mellers is “knowledgeable, engaging, and approachable.” Students commented that Professor Mellers truly “wants everyone to learn and do well”. Professor Mellers expressed an “Incredible amount of expertise” that she was able to share in an engaging, fun, and interesting way.   Students agreed that the grading for the course “was a lot tougher than expected” and sometimes seemed “random”. However, several students commented that Professor Mellers “is more than willing to sit down and discuss grades” in order to help. The group project for the course elicited mixed reviews, with some students finding it “challenging” and exciting, and others seeing less value in it.
